Award.AwardTitle: Eigenvalues, geometry and instability in conservative models in applied mathematics.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Most of the equations derived to model physical phenomena support some form
of special solutions such as standing or traveling waves, or other coherent
structures. These special solutions often correspond to real, observable
physical phenomena in the systems that these model equations are meant to
represent. One important aspect of this modeling is the stability of these
special solutions, as the stability of solutions determines if these
solutions are likely to be physically observed. This project is aimed at
understanding the stability and instability these coherent structures.
This usually amounts to computing the index of the operator found by
linearizing about one of these coherent structures - that is the number of
eigenvalues of positive real part. This counts the dimension of the
unstable manifold to the solution, giving valuable information on the
dynamics of nearby solutions. While the emphasis of this project is on
conservative systems we consider both conservative and dissipative systems.
We use analytical, asymptotic and geometric techniques to identify unstable
eigenvalues and to count the number of such eigenvalues.

There are many mathematical models that are important for science and
engineering that support solutions in the form of traveling waves. One
example is an equation known as the Korteweg-DeVries equation, an equation
which governs the behavior of water in a narrow shallow body such as a
canal. The Korteweg-DeVries equation has solutions called solitary waves
which behave just as experience would suggest - they correspond to a
quantity of water which propagates along without changing shape. Similar
equations govern the propagation of light waves, propagation of a
disturbance through a network such as the power grid, etc. It is
important to understand the extent to which these solutions accurately
model the behavior of the underlying system. This is the question of
stability, which measures how robust these special solutions are. If a
special solution like a traveling wave is stable it means that nearby
solutions behave in a similar way. This means such solutions are robust,
and are likely to be observed: if the conditions are not exactly those
necessary to produce a traveling wave but are close we expect to see a
solution which is close to the special one. An unstable solution, on the
other hand, is not robust. In order to observe these unstable solution
one must produce exactly the right conditions, which is very difficult
to achieve in practice. This means that such solutions are more of
mathematical interest than of physical importance. This project is
primarily concerned with developing mathematical techniques to understand
the stability of traveling waves in a number of models including the
Kuramoto model (a model for the behavior of power networks) and several
nonlinear dispersive equations (which govern light waves in nonlinear
media, water waves, waves in plasmas and many other phenomena).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on understanding the stability properties of coherent structures to nonlinear equations. Coherent structures, such as traveling and standing waves and periodic solutions are physically interesting because these are structures that are often observed in experiments. Stability is concerned with understanding the robustness of these solutions: do they persist under changes in conditions. We have made substantial progress in understanding the stability of structures for a number of equations. One such equation is the Kuramoto system of coupled oscillators. This is a fundamental model for the synchronization of oscillators, and it governs very diverse phenomenon: from the  synchronization of the blinking of fireflies to the synchronization of electrical generators in the national electrical grid. The figure shows the simplest example: a plot of the set of parameters for three oscialltors where there exists a stable synchronized solution. In this project we proved new results that help illuminate both the question of how such systems synchronize, and how this synchrony can be disrupted. One result, for instance, gives a new dual formulation for the entire question of stability, allowing the question of stability to be reformulated on the cycle space of the network, a topological idea connected with "loops" in the system. Essentially this helps to elucidate the role of redundancy in the network in setting up an maintaining synchrony.  This particular result is most applicable to sparse graphs, where the dimension of the cycle space is much smaller than the dimension of the network itself. This condition is met for actual electrical networks, like the North American electrical grid, where the dimension of the cycle space is typically twenty to thirty percent of the dimension of the network itself. We have also proved new results for general networks that let us estimate the size of the regions of parameter space that allow synchronized solutions.

Intellectual Meri: These results bring together a variety of mathematical techniques, including algebraic graph theory, some simple topology, as well as eigenvalue analysis to prove some interesting new results about an important model problem. These techniques are likely to find application in many other problems in the general area of dynamics on networks.

Broader Impacts: The models that have been studied in this project have numerous applications, most notably to the study of the electrical network, and lead to a greater understanding of how to improve the stability of networks. As mentioned above the tools developed here are quite general and are likely to have applications beyond the Kuramoto model.
